text: - [Kirk] Hi, I'm Kirk Davis,
a specialist solutions architect
on the Microsoft platform team at AWS.
Today I'm going to show you

some of the powerful capabilities
of Amazon Q Developer
to speed up .NET development in the IDE.

Amazon Q Developer is a coding
and conversational assistant
powered by generative AI
that can help you develop, extend,
and understand applications for AWS.
Q Developer can chat about code,

provide inline code completions,
generate new functionality.

It can scan your code for
security vulnerabilities
and make improvements to it.

Q Developer is available in
a lot of different places,
depending in part

on whether you're using
the Pro tier or not.

Today I'm talking about
using it in your IDE,
but you can also access Q Developer
from the AWS Management Console
and other places where you work.
It's also built into Amazon Code Catalyst,

AWS's unified software
development service.

Amazon Q Developers code
suggestions are based
on large language models, or LLMs,
trained on billions of lines of code,
including open source and Amazon code.

And Q is constantly
updating its capabilities

to give you the most
contextually relevant answers.
If you're a .NET developer,

you probably spend your time
coding in one of these IDEs,
either Visual Studio. VS Code,
or a JetBrains IDE like Rider.

So Amazon Q Developer is
available as an extension
or toolkit for each of these.

The toolkits for VS
Code and JetBrains IDEs

Now, one of the most powerful features

of Amazon Q Developer is the
agent for software development,

where you can go from a
natural language prompt
that you type in to an application feature

with interactive step-by-step
instructions right in the IDE,

'cause Q understands
your workspace structure
and it uses your prompt to create a plan
to accomplish whatever you're asking
with logical implementation steps,
which can include generating new code,

creating unit tests, doing
API integrations and more.
You can collaborate with Q to review
and iterate on the plan that it creates.

And then when you're ready,
Q can implement each step,

generating new files and
updating existing ones.
So in this example, you can see I ask Q
to create a new class in C# to save a log
of all the JWT tokens that are generated

a little while ago

Like before you implement
